annual uptime Institute survey they took a look at power
PUA power usage effectiveness now it turns out from us this gets even better because we spend a lot of time

PUA if you're not familiar with it pee-wee is that measure of the amount of energy that is required to pull from the
grid to support your critical compute so the closer to one you get the better if
you have a one PUA it means that for every unit of power required to support
your critical resources you're taking one from the grid whereas if you had a
1.9 that meant that 1.9 units of power were pulled to support one unit of
critical compute now at that point nine you might wonder where it goes
turns out it's used by chillers air handlers whereas simply wasted in the distribution process so again the closer

Institute the uptime Institute found that the average Enterprise Data Center ran at a PUA of one point seven now one

a one point zero seven to one point one five PUA now to simplify this
calculation and to be a little conservative I'm going to use one point two for this illustration with one point
two you use 71% of the power from the grid on the cloud than you would from an

fact in some places they are crash rated fences where a vehicle cannot break through them and in other places they're
not crash rated but they're backed by jersey barriers like you might see on a freeway or in a construction site many
of our sites have internal trip light perimeters that set off alarms and each
are managed and monitored 24 by 7 by a security force now once you get past
that first perimeter our next perimeter is at the building and that building
requires a badge swipe dual authenticate badge swipe where you have to have the right badge and a personalized pin in

some cases generators the only people
who have access to these rooms are the engineers who need to work on it each of

there are guards in a local area that monitor it as well as a remote facility that also monitor it and at the
slightest indication of an issue a guard is dispatched now that gets to the final
area of our security strategy and that's our data halls where the servers and

plus a pin but to even get to that door you need to have gone through the first perimeter and then the building

- fiber paths coming out of every one of our ACS and data centers each of these are physically separated so they can't
